A microsimulation of an economic activity is constructed by assembling an appropriate cast of characters, and fitting out each individual person or firm with a set of behavioral rules.
body_text.section: Constructing a Computer-Simulated Scenario and Watching It Play Out

body_text.text: An actor in the simulation will "exist" in the computer's memory space as a collection of pieces of information, rather like the record of an actual person's account in the computer of a brokerage house, which is updated each time a transaction is made.
body_text.section: Constructing a Computer-Simulated Scenario and Watching It Play Out

body_text.text: The analyst may derive the behavioral rules for the actors from a theory depicting a utility-maximizing process of choice, from a regression study on Census data, from a laboratory experiment with human subjects, or may simply make up rules that seem reasonably realistic or that are merely serviceable to the analytic task at hand.
body_text.section: Constructing a Computer-Simulated Scenario and Watching It Play Out

body_text.text: Wherever the rules come from, all the functional forms and parameter values must be specified for each run of the simulation on the computer.
body_text.section: Constructing a Computer-Simulated Scenario and Watching It Play Out

body_text.text: The analyst must also set highly specific ground rules for the simulated interactions of the individuals (or firms) with each other.
body_text.section: Constructing a Computer-Simulated Scenario and Watching It Play Out

body_text.text: Interactions are recorded as they occur.
body_text.section: Constructing a Computer-Simulated Scenario and Watching It Play Out

body_text.text: Numerical reports summarizing the action are issued at suitable intervals, as Dow Jones indexes are issued during the trading day, or unemployment rates are issued each month.
body_text.section: Constructing a Computer-Simulated Scenario and Watching It Play Out

body_text.text: The analyst uses the reports to try to make generalizations about how the specified micro situation, as well as any exogenous events, have affected the simulated macro outcomes.
body_text.section: Constructing a Computer-Simulated Scenario and Watching It Play Out

body_text.text: Microsimulation models have a number of advantages over conventional methods used by economists.
body_text.section: Constructing a Computer-Simulated Scenario and Watching It Play Out

body_text.text: One advantage is the explicitness with which the interactions on the micro level can be depicted.
body_text.section: Constructing a Computer-Simulated Scenario and Watching It Play Out

body_text.text: Conventional methods of economic analysis often provide cogent derivations of individuals' contingency plans, but tend to be weak in describing the process that allows all the contingency plans to mesh together.
body_text.section: Constructing a Computer-Simulated Scenario and Watching It Play Out

body_text.text: Highly mathematical accounts of the derivation of individuals' behavior rules are not infrequently followed by vague verbal descriptions of what goes on when the individuals come together and interact.
body_text.section: Constructing a Computer-Simulated Scenario and Watching It Play Out

body_text.text: This vagueness can lead to error, as has been the case in the labor market issues discussed below.
body_text.section: Constructing a Computer-Simulated Scenario and Watching It Play Out

body_text.text: Simulation can be especially helpful in dealing with problems of information and expectations.
body_text.section: Constructing a Computer-Simulated Scenario and Watching It Play Out

body_text.text: The model builder can specify in a precise way the information the actors come to have as the action proceeds, the expectations they form, and how they react to that knowledge and those expectations.
body_text.section: Constructing a Computer-Simulated Scenario and Watching It Play Out

body_text.text: The actors can be allowed to be led into mistakes by their decision rules, suffer from their mistakes, and even learn from them.
body_text.section: Constructing a Computer-Simulated Scenario and Watching It Play Out

body_text.text: Another advantage of simulation models is that they can be set up to be completely recursive, as real life is.
body_text.section: Constructing a Computer-Simulated Scenario and Watching It Play Out

body_text.text: The elimination of simultaneous equations allows us to get results from a simulation model without having to go through a process of solution.
body_text.section: Constructing a Computer-Simulated Scenario and Watching It Play Out

body_text.text: Instead one gets the computer to play out the scenario and analyzes the numerical outcome, which may or may not achieve an equilibrium.
body_text.section: Constructing a Computer-Simulated Scenario and Watching It Play Out

body_text.text: Models that don't have to be solved can be changed or added to freely and easily, as exemplified below.
body_text.section: Constructing a Computer-Simulated Scenario and Watching It Play Out

body_text.text: Nonlinearities, switches of regime, and other complexities are easily accommodated.
body_text.section: Constructing a Computer-Simulated Scenario and Watching It Play Out

body_text.text: A number of small-scale simulation models have been built to explore subjects that conventional methods handle only awkwardly, if at all.
body_text.section: Constructing a Computer-Simulated Scenario and Watching It Play Out

body_text.text: For example, Nelson, Winter, and Schuette (1976) modeled the spread and effects of technical change.
body_text.section: Constructing a Computer-Simulated Scenario and Watching It Play Out

body_text.text: Individual firms were depicted discovering and trying out new modes of production, or imitating successful competitors.
body_text.section: Constructing a Computer-Simulated Scenario and Watching It Play Out

body_text.text: The hiring, capital purchases, and profits of every firm at each moment in time were kept track of, and parameter values were found that allowed the model's simulated macrodata to track U.S. macrodata on income and productivity.
body_text.section: Constructing a Computer-Simulated Scenario and Watching It Play Out

body_text.text: In other examples, Bergmann (1973) simulated U.S. poverty rates by tracking the incomes of simulated individuals as unemployment rates and wage rates changed in accordance with historical patterns.
body_text.section: Constructing a Computer-Simulated Scenario and Watching It Play Out

body_text.text: Pryor (1973) looked at the effect of marriage and inheritance patterns on income distribution through many generations.
body_text.section: Constructing a Computer-Simulated Scenario and Watching It Play Out

body_text.text: He simulated individuals picking spouses, accumulating assets, having children, dying, and leaving an inheritance to one or more of the children.
body_text.section: Constructing a Computer-Simulated Scenario and Watching It Play Out

body_text.text: His model displays the resulting trends in the degree of inequality by computing simulated time series of Gini coefficients based on the simulated microdata.
body_text.section: Constructing a Computer-Simulated Scenario and Watching It Play Out

body_text.text: Pryor's model can be embodied in a program of 75 lines.
body_text.section: Constructing a Computer-Simulated Scenario and Watching It Play Out

body_text.text: Large-scale microsimulation models that sum to national income accounts have been built by Eliason for Sweden (1976), by Adelman and Robinson for Korea (1978), and by Bennett and Bergmann for the United States (1986).
body_text.section: Constructing a Computer-Simulated Scenario and Watching It Play Out

body_text.text: For studies of policy, simulation models offer an opportunity to embed into a formal model a realistic description of how a regulation, tax, or subsidy affects the economic actors.
body_text.section: Constructing a Computer-Simulated Scenario and Watching It Play Out

body_text.text: (See Orcutt, Caldwell and Wertheimer, 1976;Haveman and Hollenbeck, 1980).
body_text.section: Constructing a Computer-Simulated Scenario and Watching It Play Out

body_text.text: Our delineation here of unemployment insurance shows how a government program with nonlinear rules can easily be added to a simulation model with a very few additional computer instructions.
body_text.section: Constructing a Computer-Simulated Scenario and Watching It Play Out

body_text.text: Simulation models can also serve as a theoretical framework for empirical studies, just as conventional models can.
body_text.section: Constructing a Computer-Simulated Scenario and Watching It Play Out

body_text.text: Data can be used to estimate a model's parameters and to gauge its goodness of fit (Bergmann, 1974;1989).
body_text.section: Constructing a Computer-Simulated Scenario and Watching It Play Out

body_text.text: Of course, simulation models have their drawbacks.
body_text.section: Constructing a Computer-Simulated Scenario and Watching It Play Out

body_text.text: When using them, the analyst has to give up the formal or informal deduction used in conventional models and has to rely instead on inductive analysis of numerical results.
body_text.section: Constructing a Computer-Simulated Scenario and Watching It Play Out

body_text.text: This may be less certain and is certainly less entertaining.
body_text.section: Constructing a Computer-Simulated Scenario and Watching It Play Out

body_text.text: Drawing qualitative generalizations from the numerical results is fraught with the possibility of error.
body_text.section: Constructing a Computer-Simulated Scenario and Watching It Play Out

body_text.text: The very ease with which new detail can be added to simulation models poses a danger.
body_text.section: Constructing a Computer-Simulated Scenario and Watching It Play Out

body_text.text: When the models grow more complex, the job of checking their cogency, of rooting out bugs, and interpreting and generalizing from their results becomes more problematical.
body_text.section: Constructing a Computer-Simulated Scenario and Watching It Play Out

body_text.text: A simulation study can explore what happens when the actors follow optimizing behavioral rules, as in Fair (1974).
body_text.section: Constructing a Computer-Simulated Scenario and Watching It Play Out

body_text.text: But simulations can just as easily explore what happens when the actors follow rules of thumb which have not been proved out as optimal.
body_text.section: Constructing a Computer-Simulated Scenario and Watching It Play Out

body_text.text: Such simulations may seem sleazy to those economists for whom respectable microeconomics is synonymous with solving optimization problems.
body_text.section: Constructing a Computer-Simulated Scenario and Watching It Play Out

body_text.text: They fear that simulation opens the door to a loss of quality control in the profession, if the stringent paradigm of mathematical specification and solution for optima is relaxed.
body_text.section: Constructing a Computer-Simulated Scenario and Watching It Play Out

body_text.text: However, the way to make an optimum decision is not known in many important economic arenas that deserve economists' attention and analysis.
body_text.section: Constructing a Computer-Simulated Scenario and Watching It Play Out

body_text.text: Sometimes the actor does not have the information that economic theory assumes, like a reliable demand curve for one's product, or a good line on what one's competitor is likely to do.
body_text.section: Constructing a Computer-Simulated Scenario and Watching It Play Out

body_text.text: Sometimes there is too much information around, and it is difficult to process it all.
body_text.section: Constructing a Computer-Simulated Scenario and Watching It Play Out

body_text.text: Sometimes the actor cannot be presumed to know the optimization technique.
body_text.section: Constructing a Computer-Simulated Scenario and Watching It Play Out

body_text.text: In such cases, simulated experimentation with the effects of varying rules of thumb may be the nearest possible approach to optimization.
body_text.section: Constructing a Computer-Simulated Scenario and Watching It Play Out

body_text.text: Some empirical research (Tversky and Kahneman, 1988; Thaler's columns in this Journal) suggests that human beings are apt to follow rules that produce results that are inferior to those obtained with rules that economists might devise.
body_text.section: Constructing a Computer-Simulated Scenario and Watching It Play Out

body_text.text: Where this is the case, simulations of non-optimal but empirically true behavior patterns should yield more realistic predictions than normative theories that are empirically false.
body_text.section: Constructing a Computer-Simulated Scenario and Watching It Play Out

body_text.text: Obviously, simulation models that depict individuals who endlessly repeat obvious mistakes deserve condemnation, and all models can benefit from criticism.
body_text.section: Constructing a Computer-Simulated Scenario and Watching It Play Out

body_text.text: But treating the simulation methodology itself as entirely taboo cuts out a lot of valuable possibilities for exploration.
body_text.section: Constructing a Computer-Simulated Scenario and Watching It Play Out

body_text.text: Economists need more tools in our kits, not fewer.
body_text.section: Constructing a Computer-Simulated Scenario and Watching It Play Out

body_text.text: Let me now turn to an example that will display some of the advantages and disadvantages of the simulation methodology.
body_text.section: Constructing a Computer-Simulated Scenario and Watching It Play Out

body_text.text: The reader, after studying it, can draw his or her own conclusions.
body_text.section: Constructing a Computer-Simulated Scenario and Watching It Play Out

body_text.text: The labor market makes a good subject for simulation, since the results of the search process of individuals are not easy to represent as functions, or to aggregate.
body_text.section: An Example of Labor Market Simulation

body_text.text: The demand side of the market and the interactions of workers with potential employers, which have been left rather vague in much of the current literature, can be fleshed out.
body_text.section: An Example of Labor Market Simulation

body_text.text: Much conventional analysis of the labor market concentrates on the individual unemployed worker who searches for a job and finds an ample array of vacancies for his or her consideration.
body_text.section: An Example of Labor Market Simulation

body_text.text: In each period, the utility-maximizing worker weighs the benefits of taking one of these available jobs at the offered wage against the benefits of remaining unemployed.
body_text.section: An Example of Labor Market Simulation

body_text.text: Unemployed people are then thought of, following Lucas and Rapping (1969), as a group of workers who could have taken jobs at some wage or other, but chose otherwise.
body_text.section: An Example of Labor Market Simulation

body_text.text: Anything that increases the propensity of some workers to refuse employment is viewed as increasing the number of unemployed.
body_text.section: An Example of Labor Market Simulation

body_text.text: The microsimulation approach presented here seeks to develop a dynamic portrayal of the action on the microeconomic level that characterizes the behavior of individual workers but also the behavior of employers, rejecting the usual implicit assumption of unlimited job availability.
body_text.section: An Example of Labor Market Simulation

body_text.text: The model also sets a protocol for the interactions of employers and unemployed workers.
body_text.section: An Example of Labor Market Simulation

body_text.text: After these steps have been taken, one can run the simulation program, and watch unemployed workers searching for jobs, interacting with employers who have empty job slots they want to fill.
body_text.section: An Example of Labor Market Simulation

body_text.text: An unemployment insurance system is added to this simulated labor market, complete with eligibility requirements and limited-time benefits.
body_text.section: An Example of Labor Market Simulation

body_text.text: Then, by running the model again, we can see what difference the unemployment insurance program makes to the unemployment rate.
body_text.section: An Example of Labor Market Simulation

body_text.text: To preview the results, the simulation will show that, contrary to the claims of conventional analysts, refusals of job offers by stipend-receiving malingerers does not in all circumstances increase the number of unemployed people.
body_text.section: An Example of Labor Market Simulation

body_text.text: The simulation avoids a narrow focus on the isolated choice of a single worker, thus bringing to visibility a point that conventional analysts tend to lose sight of as they verbally pass from the micro to the macro: that the refusal of one worker to take a particular job allows another worker a shot at that vacancy.
body_text.section: An Example of Labor Market Simulation

body_text.text: The core of the model is an extremely simple representation of worker movements into and out of jobs.
body_text.section: The Simulation Technique

body_text.text: It is written in BASIC, a close analogue to FORTRAN.

body_text.section: The Simulation Technique

body_text.text: In this simple model, workers will be homogeneous as to skills and other characteristics, and all will be equally acceptable to employers for all jobs.
body_text.section: The Simulation Technique

body_text.text: Considerations relating to wage levels, either on the supply side or the demand side, will be pushed under the rug.

body_text.text: (The significance of this formulation is discussed below.)
body_text.section: The Simulation Technique

body_text.text: The number of jobs that employers want to fill each week will be exogenously determined: fed into the computer as data.
body_text.section: The Simulation Technique

body_text.text: Workers, after a brief period of search, will take any job that is offered.
body_text.section: The Simulation Technique

body_text.text: The size of the labor force will be constant.
body_text.section: The Simulation Technique

body_text.text: If the analyst desires a more realistic model, all of these features can be changed quite easily.
body_text.section: The Simulation Technique

body_text.text: Each "week," the actors in the model carry out a round of simulated activities.
body_text.section: The Simulation Technique

body_text.text: The micro-level scenario for a week is as follows: First, employers decide on the stock of jobs they wish to have filled this week.
body_text.section: The Simulation Technique

body_text.text: Some workers will be laid off, others will quit.
body_text.section: The Simulation Technique

body_text.text: The workers to be separated from jobs are picked at random from the ranks of the employed to join the ranks of the unemployed.
body_text.section: The Simulation Technique

body_text.text: After the separations have occurred, the unemployed (including some separated in previous periods who have not yet taken jobs) search for job vacancies; some are chosen at random to come to an interview, and some of these agree to become employed.
body_text.section: The Simulation Technique

body_text.text: At the end of the weekly activity, the "Census Bureau" surveys the situations of all the simulated individuals.
body_text.section: The Simulation Technique

body_text.text: It notes whether they are in a state of unemployment, and how long that state has persisted.
body_text.section: The Simulation Technique

body_text.text: It "publishes" simulated macro-data based on its survey: the unemployment rate and the average of unemployment durations.

body_text.section: Results of Running the Simulation

body_text.text: The macroseries shown in Figure 1 were generated by a single run of the model in Table 2.
body_text.section: Results of Running the Simulation

body_text.text: The fall and subsequent recovery in job availability produces changes in the average length of unemployment spells that are more complex than one might have imagined.
body_text.section: Results of Running the Simulation

body_text.text: As unemployment starts to rise, average duration of uncompleted spells falls for a time.
body_text.section: Results of Running the Simulation

body_text.text: This results from the increase in the number of newly unemployed people, whose spells so far are short.
body_text.section: Results of Running the Simulation

body_text.text: However, unemployed workers experience increasing difficulty in re-entering employment, as more of them are vying for a slightly smaller number of openings.
body_text.section: Results of Running the Simulation

body_text.text: So average duration starts to increase.
body_text.section: Results of Running the Simulation

body_text.text: Durations start to fall only after the recovery in demand has been going on for some time, but then fall rapidly.

body_text.text: The focus of the simulation presented here is not, "How will utility maximizing individuals behave?"
body_text.section: Final Comments

body_text.text: Rather, I have specified a particular behavioral pattern for the actors and asked, "What will the mechanical result of their interactions be?"
body_text.section: Final Comments

body_text.text: Even though the actors are not depicted as fervid optimizers, the simulation does shed light on the pattern of spell durations over the cycle and on the effect of unemployment insurance on unemployment rates, which were goals of the analysis.
body_text.section: Final Comments

body_text.text: Of course, one could construct a model in which the simulated actors behaved with greater rationality.
body_text.section: Final Comments

body_text.text: For example, one might try to depict them optimizing the degree of their malingering.
body_text.section: Final Comments

body_text.text: They might be shown calculating, as the expiration date of their unemployment insurance benefits grows nearer, the probability that the failure to accept an offer now will lead to a period of unemployment without benefits later.
body_text.section: Final Comments

body_text.text: The analyst might assume that a mathematical derivation of the optimal malingering rule is within the workers' capabilities.
body_text.section: Final Comments

body_text.text: Unfortunately, it is not within the present author's.
body_text.section: Final Comments

body_text.text: But it is unlikely that a simulation model with actors more inclined toward finding and following optimal rules of behavior would give answers that differ qualitatively from those given by this model.
body_text.section: Final Comments

body_text.text: The nonoptimizing actors of this model were servicable for the analysis we aimed at.
body_text.section: Final Comments

body_text.text: The reader should remember, moreover, that the simulation model with nonoptimizing actors provided better insights about how unemployment is generated than the conventional models depicting allegedly optimizing actors.
